Name: zirconium sponge production, from zirconium tetrachloride | zirconium sponge, nuclear-grade | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals
Description: The hafnium-free ZrCl4 is placed in a furnace at 800-850◦C and is subsequently reduced through the addition of magnesium. The stoichiometric equation is the following: ZrCl4 + 2 Mg → Zr + 2 MgCl2. The resulting zirconium is a spongelike material, hence the name zirconium sponge. The zirconium sponge undergoes vacuum distillation, where the sponge is purified by removing the magnesium chloride, which is then separated via the electrolysis process, producing magnesium and chlorine (MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2). After refining, the magnesium is recycled and serves again as input to the reduction process, while chlorine (after it is filtrated and purified) is recycled and sent back to the chlorination process as an input. The zirconium sponge is then crushed to small pieces to ensure easier transport and handling.
